A Radio Station Looks At
American Education
The factors that go to make up the educational crisis in America
have begun to impinge themselves on the consciousness of the
American people with increasing force. The nation's schools are
bulging at the seams. Enrollment of school children will increase
by almost 9 million within the next 5 to 6 years. More than 50,000
new teachers will be required to handle this increased work load.
Another 75,000 teachers will be needed to replace those who nor¬
mally retire or leave the profession. Adequate school buildings,
not to mention teachers, during the next 6 years would cost more
than 25 billion dollars. Although States and local communities are
spending about 500 million dollars more in 1954 than last year,
it is obvious that even current needs have not been met.
WNYC as a municipally-operated non-commercial radio station
is attempting in this Educational Institute of the Air to examine in
depth the American educational scene. A full week of broadcasting
will be devoted to an appraisal of how educational processes are
carried on—from the nursery to the adult level—and to a thought-
inspiring survey of the job which must be done for tomorrow's
education.
We do not delude ourselves that any of our listeners will be
glued to the radio receiver over the entire 6-day period. Neverthe¬
less, we feel it a proper function of a municipal medium of com¬
munication in a democracy to make audible the latest thought on
an important problem. In essence, this is a week-long radio docu¬
mentary which we hope will stimulate citizen thinking in an im¬
portant area.
It is only a beginning, but, if our listeners are inspired to pro¬
ceed with deeper and stronger analysis, we shall have rendered
a great public service.
The Educational Institute of the Air is produced by WNYC
under the terms of a grant from the Edward L. Bernays Foundation
to the National Association of Educational Broadcasters. The pro¬
gram co-ordinator for all of the programs has been Mrs. Anne W.
Langman to whom great thanks is due. Special mention must be
made of the yeoman service rendered by members of the staff of
WNYC, its Program Director Bernard R. Buck and the Assistant
Program Director, A. Alan Levin. It is impossible in this space to
individually enumerate the large number of distinguished educa¬
tors and scholars without whose advice and assistance this project
could not have been launched, but our gratitude is not thereby
diminished.
SEYMOUR N. SIEGEL
Director of Radio Communications
